title: What causes the phases of the moon?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary source of light in the solar system?

options.label: A
options.text: The Earth

options.label: B
options.text: The Moon

options.label: C
options.text: The Sun

options.label: D
options.text: The stars

multiple-choice.question: Why don't we see a lunar eclipse every full moon?

options.label: A
options.text: The Earth's shadow is too small to cover the Moon

options.label: B
options.text: The Moon's orbit is tilted slightly to the Earth's orbit around the Sun

options.label: C
options.text: The Sun's light is too strong to be blocked by the Earth

options.label: D
options.text: The Moon is too far away from the Earth

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the light that passes through the Earth's atmosphere during a lunar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: It is completely blocked by the Earth's shadow

options.label: B
options.text: It is refracted towards the Moon, with the blue light being scattered out

options.label: C
options.text: It is reflected back to the Earth, causing a bright ring around the Moon

options.label: D
options.text: It is absorbed by the Earth's atmosphere, causing the Moon to disappear

multiple-choice.question: Why is studying lunar eclipses important for scientists?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps us understand the Earth's atmosphere

options.label: B
options.text: It helps us detect exoplanets orbiting around other stars

options.label: C
options.text: It helps us study the Moon's surface

options.label: D
options.text: It helps us predict solar eclipses

multiple-choice.question: What can scientists detect in the Earth's atmosphere by studying the spectrum of light reflected off the Moon during a lunar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: Only ozone and carbon dioxide

options.label: B
options.text: Only water vapor and methane

options.label: C
options.text: A variety of gases, including ozone, carbon dioxide, water vapor, and methane

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

title: How well do masks work?

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: To reduce the economic impact of the pandemic

title: Am I Really A Visual Learner?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the concept of learning styles?

options.label: A
options.text: That people have different preferences for learning, but it doesn't affect their actual learning.

options.label: B
options.text: That people have inherent traits that affect how well they learn in different presentation formats.

options.label: C
options.text: That people can only learn in one specific way.

options.label: D
options.text: That people should only be taught in their preferred learning style.

multiple-choice.question: According to a 2008 review, how many studies found that students learned best with their preferred learning style?
What was a major flaw in the one study that found students learned best with their preferred learning style?

options.label: A
options.text: The researchers didn't use a large enough sample size.

options.label: B
options.text: The researchers excluded two-thirds of the original participants.

options.label: C
options.text: The researchers didn't use a control group.

options.label: D
options.text: The researchers didn't report the actual test scores.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That visual learners did better when they saw the words.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: That everyone did better when they heard the words.

multiple-choice.question: What is a conclusion that can be drawn from the studies on learning styles?

options.label: A
options.text: That people should only be taught in their preferred learning style.

options.label: B
options.text: That people have inherent traits that affect how well they learn in different presentation formats.

options.label: C
options.text: That most people seem to learn better when taught in several ways, especially if one is visual.

options.label: D
options.text: That learning styles don't matter at all.

title: What happens when nature goes viral?

multiple-choice.question: What was the main trigger for the sudden increase in visitors to Horseshoe Bend?

options.label: A
options.text: A big marketing push

options.label: B
options.text: Social media

options.label: C
options.text: Improved infrastructure

options.label: D
options.text: Word of mouth

multiple-choice.question: What is geotagging, and how has it contributed to the popularity of hidden spots like Horseshoe Bend?

options.label: A
options.text: Geotagging is the practice of attaching location data to a picture, and it has made it easier for people to find and visit these spots.

options.label: B
options.text: Geotagging is the practice of sharing pictures on social media, and it has increased the popularity of these spots by making them more visible.

options.label: C
options.text: Geotagging is the practice of creating new location tags for hidden spots, and it has contributed to the popularity of these spots by making them more accessible.

options.label: D
options.text: Geotagging is the practice of searching for pictures of hidden spots, and it has increased the popularity of these spots by making them more discoverable.

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the negative consequences of the increased popularity of hidden spots like Horseshoe Bend?

options.label: A
options.text: The natural landscape can be damaged, and people following geotagging trends are at risk of injury or death.

options.label: B
options.text: The local economy can be boosted, and the spot can become a popular tourist destination.

options.label: C
options.text: The spot can become overcrowded, and the experience can be ruined for visitors.

options.label: D
options.text: The spot can become more accessible, and people with disabilities can visit more easily.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Leave No Trace organization, and what is their stance on geotagging?

options.label: A
options.text: Leave No Trace is an organization that promotes responsible outdoor recreation, and they encourage people to geotag photos to raise awareness about the importance of conservation.

options.label: B
options.text: Leave No Trace is an organization that promotes responsible outdoor recreation, and they discourage people from geotagging photos to protect the environment.

options.label: C
options.text: Leave No Trace is an organization that promotes outdoor recreation, and they have no stance on geotagging.

options.label: D
options.text: Leave No Trace is an organization that promotes conservation, and they encourage people to geotag photos to track the impact of human activity on the environment.

multiple-choice.question: What is the city of Page doing to address the increased popularity of Horseshoe Bend?

options.label: A
options.text: They are creating a new trail and improving infrastructure to accommodate more visitors.

options.label: B
options.text: They are limiting the number of visitors to protect the environment.

options.label: C
options.text: They are promoting the spot on social media to attract more visitors.

options.label: D
options.text: They are doing nothing to address the increased popularity.

title: Why does smoke follow you around a fire?

multiple-choice.question: What happens to air molecules when they absorb heat from a fire?

options.label: A
options.text: They slow down and become denser.

options.label: B
options.text: They start to move faster and become less dense.

options.label: C
options.text: They remain unchanged.

options.label: D
options.text: They start to vibrate in place.

multiple-choice.question: Why does less-dense air rise?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it weighs less than the air it replaces.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is pushed up by the air around it.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is pulled down by gravity less than the air around it pushes it up.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is denser than the air around it.

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon called when hot air rises and is replaced by cooler air?

options.label: A
options.text: Conduction

options.label: B
options.text: Convection

options.label: C
options.text: Radiation

options.label: D
options.text: Evaporation

multiple-choice.question: Why does smoke tend to blow into your face when you move around a fire?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the fire is cursed.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the air around the fire is denser than the air near you.

options.label: C
options.text: Because your body blocks the air behind you from moving toward the fire, creating a vacuum.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the smoke is attracted to your face.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a smokeless fire pit?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a stronger vacuum to blow smoke into your face.

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce or eliminate smoke production by creating additional paths for incoming air.

options.label: C
options.text: To make the fire burn hotter.

options.label: D
options.text: To make the fire burn longer.

title: The physics of a pool vortex

multiple-choice.question: What is formed when a plate is dragged through the water in a pool?

options.label: A
options.text: A wave

options.label: B
options.text: A ripple

options.label: C
options.text: A vortex

options.label: D
options.text: A bubble

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are two separate vortices

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are connected by a half vortex ring

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are moving at the same speed

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are dissipating energy

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Water waves travel faster than light and sound waves.

options.label: D
options.text: Water waves travel slower than light and sound waves.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Diffraction

options.label: D
options.text: Interference

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: How ingenious animals have engineered air conditioning

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem that termites, prairie dogs, and humans face when living in closed spaces?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of food

options.label: B
options.text: Lack of water

options.label: C
options.text: Buildup of CO2

options.label: D
options.text: Overcrowding

multiple-choice.question: How do termites ventilate their mounds to keep the air fresh?

options.label: A
options.text: Using giant machines to bring in fresh air and pump stale air out

options.label: B
options.text: Through tiny holes in the outer walls and a temperature-driven ventilation system

options.label: C
options.text: By building lower entrances nearby to draw in air

options.label: D
options.text: By using the Coandă effect to draw air out of the mound

multiple-choice.question: What is the Coandă effect, and how do ants use it to ventilate their colonies?

options.label: A
options.text: The Coandă effect is the friction of fluids, and ants use it to pull air out of their colonies by building lower entrances nearby

options.label: B
options.text: The Coandă effect is the force of air hitting a surface, and ants use it to push air into their colonies

options.label: C
options.text: The Coandă effect is the viscosity of fluids, and ants use it to draw air out of their colonies by building lower entrances nearby

options.label: D
options.text: The Coandă effect is the movement of air over a surface, and ants use it to ventilate their colonies by building taller hills

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how humans have used a similar structure to cool buildings?

options.label: A
options.text: Using giant machines to bring in fresh air and pump stale air out

options.label: B
options.text: Building lower entrances nearby to draw in air

options.label: C
options.text: Using the Coandă effect to draw air out of buildings

options.label: D
options.text: Persian and Egyptian architects have used windcatchers to cool buildings for centuries
